name: LogicLibrary
title: Logic Library
publisher: Health Level Seven, Inc. - CDS WG
description: The logic library profile sets the minimum expectations for computable and/or executable libraries, including support for terminology and dependency declaration, parameters, and data requirements

element.short: Represents a library of quality improvement components
element.definition: The Library resource is a general-purpose container for knowledge asset definitions. It can be used to describe and expose existing knowledge assets such as logic libraries and information model descriptions, as well as to describe a collection of knowledge assets.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Defines a knowledge capability afforded by this knowledge artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Defines a knowledge representation level provided by this knowledge artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Additional documentation, review, or usage guidance
element.definition: A comment containing additional documentation, a review comment, usage guidance, or other relevant information from a particular user.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: A code directly referenced by the artifact
element.definition: Defines a code directly referenced by artifact logic, as opposed to a value set. Direct reference codes may be the target of data requirements.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this library, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this library when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this library is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the library is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the library to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this library when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance. e.g. CMS or NQF identifiers for a measure artifact. Note that at least one identifier is required for non-experimental active artifacts.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this library outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the library when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the library author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). For more information on versioning knowledge assets, refer to the Decision Support Service specification. Note that a version is required for non-experimental active artifacts.
element.comment: There may be different library instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the library with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A natural language name identifying the library. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the library.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An explanatory or alternate title for the library giving additional information about its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this library. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of libraries that are appropriate for use vs. not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this library is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of librarys that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level library.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Identifies the type of library such as a Logic Library, Model Definition, Asset Collection, or Module Definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of knowledge asset this library contains.

element.short: Type of individual the library content is focused on
element.definition: A code or group definition that describes the intended subject of the contents of the library.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The possible types of subjects for a library (E.g. Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the library was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the library changes.
element.comment: The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the library. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the library.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the library is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the library. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the library. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the library.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the library
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the library from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the library as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the library is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the library was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate library instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the library is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the library to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: Explanation of why this library is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the library. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this library.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Describes the clinical usage of the library
element.definition: A detailed description of how the library is used from a clinical perspective.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the library and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the library.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the library and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the library was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the library was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the library is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the library content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a library  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the library are or are expected to be used instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the library. Topics provide a high-level categorization of the library that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the library so that it can be found by topical searches.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: Libraries must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .outboundRelationship[typeCode=DOC,RSON,PREV, DRIV, USE, COMP] {successor would be PREV w/ inversionInd=true; No support for citation}

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: Libraries must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .outboundRelationship[typeCode=DOC,RSON,PREV, DRIV, USE, COMP] {successor would be PREV w/ inversionInd=true; No support for citation}

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: documentation | justification | citation | predecessor | successor | derived-from | depends-on | composed-of | part-of | amends | amended-with | appends | appended-with | cites | cited-by | comments-on | comment-in | contains | contained-in | corrects | correction-in | replaces | replaced-with | retracts | retracted-by | signs | similar-to | supports | supported-with | transforms | transformed-into | transformed-with | documents | specification-of | created-with | cite-as
element.definition: The type of relationship to the related artifact.
element.comment: The presence of both sides of a relationship type (e.g. successor and predecessor) is required to support use cases where one side of a relationship is not represented in FHIR. However, this feature SHALL NOT be used to create bi-directional resource links in FHIR instances. Specifically, following the methodology of "new points to old" and "many points to one", when using related artifact elements to describe and reference FHIR resources, the type element SHALL be drawn from the fhir-related-artifact-type ValueSet.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

extension.valueString: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

element.definition: Provides additional classifiers of the related artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

extension.valueString: Additional classifiers for the related artifact.

element.definition: A short label that can be used to reference the citation from elsewhere in the containing artifact, such as a footnote index.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Brief description of the related artifact
element.definition: A brief description of the document or knowledge resource being referenced, suitable for display to a consumer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A bibliographic citation for the related artifact. This text SHOULD be formatted according to an accepted citation format.
element.comment: Additional structured information about citations should be captured as extensions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The document being referenced, represented as an attachment. This is exclusive with the resource element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The related artifact, such as a library, value set, profile, or other knowledge resource.
element.comment: If the type is predecessor, this is a reference to the succeeding knowledge resource. If the type is successor, this is a reference to the prior knowledge resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: What artifact, if not a conformance resource
element.definition: The related artifact, if the artifact is not a canonical resource, or a resource reference to a canonical resource.
element.comment: If both resource and resourceReference are present, they SHOULD be consistent and reference the same resource. Although relatedArtifact is intended to support references to definitional resources, there are cases where non-definitional resources can be definitional (such as Location where the kind is mode). Related artifacts SHOULD be used to reference definitional resources, and profiles SHOULD be used to make that explicit for particular use cases.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The publication status of the artifact being referred to.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

extension.valueString: Publication status of an artifact being referred to.

element.short: Date of publication of the artifact being referred to
element.definition: The date of publication of the artifact being referred to.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The parameter element defines parameters used by the library.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: What data is referenced by this library
element.definition: Describes a set of data that must be provided in order to be able to successfully perform the computations defined by the library.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contents of the library, either embedded or referenced
element.definition: The content of the library as an Attachment. The content may be a reference to a url, or may be directly embedded as a base-64 string. Either way, the contentType of the attachment determines how to interpret the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
element.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
element.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

extension.valueString: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

element.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
element.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes, base64 encoded.
element.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
element.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Uri where the data can be found
element.definition: A location where the data can be accessed.
element.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
element.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

element.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
element.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment (before base64 encoding, if that is done).
element.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
element.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
element.comment: The hash is calculated on the data prior to base64 encoding, if the data is based64 encoded. The hash is not intended to support digital signatures. Where protection against malicious threats a digital signature should be considered, see [Provenance.signature](provenance-definitions.html#Provenance.signature) for mechanism to protect a resource with a digital signature.
element.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed due to technical failures (e.g., storage rot, transport glitch, incorrect version).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Label to display in place of the data
element.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
element.comment: May sometimes be derived from the source filename.
element.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
element.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The number of frames in a photo. This is used with a multi-page fax, or an imaging acquisition context that takes multiple slices in a single image, or an animated gif. If there is more than one frame, this SHALL have a value in order to alert interface software that a multi-frame capable rendering widget is required.
element.comment: if the number of frames is not supplied, the value may be unknown. Applications should not assume that there is only one frame unless it is explicitly stated.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The duration of the recording in seconds - for audio and video.
element.comment: The duration might differ from occurrencePeriod if recording was paused.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The number of pages when printed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
